10029.description: DREAM, an award winning youth development program, is seeking volunteer tutors to provide academic support to our middle school after-school students in East Harlem and the South Bronx. Tutors work with youth individually and in small groups to help improve student success in class, increase subject-specific retention, and contribute to overall academic enrichment and development. What You’ll Do Support academic enrichment activities, including homework help and tutoring; Provide individualized and team-wide support all after-school program activities and initiatives; Serve as a role model and build positive relationships with youth; What We’re Looking For Strong command of one or more of the following academic subjects: English, Math, Science, and/or Social Studies Previous experience working with youth; Possess creativity, enthusiasm, initative, flexibility, and patience; Solid oral communication skills; Ability to make a consistent, weekly commitment; Bachelor’s Degree (a plus); 1-2 years previous tutoring experience (a major plus). Benefits Gain invaluable experience and opportunities for professional development at an award winning youth development program; Receive an optional professional reference upon completion of your service term; Join an incredible community of passionate staff and volunteers. Minimum Commitment: 1-2 hours per week for 3 months. When: Monday - Thursday 4pm-5pm, 4pm-6pm, or 5:30pm-6:30pm (time depends on tutor availability and program site assignment) DREAM provides equal opportunity for all volunteers.
10029.title: Volunteer Tutor

10029.description: The Carter Burden Network, a nonprofit leader in aging services in New York City, is looking for a bright, energetic Development and Special Events Intern to join our Development team. This opportunity is great for someone who is interested in learning the ins and outs of the nonprofit sector while building skills and adding valuable work experience to their resume. This internship will provide training in DonorPerfect, one of the top CRM (customer relationship management) softwares used by nonprofits. Responsibilities: Assist with daily office tasks including data/gift entry and donor management (DonorPerfect - training provided), preparing and mailing thank you letters to donors, proofreading, preparing meeting documents etc. Assist with planning and executing special events and projects including the 2017 Gala on November 15th, 2017 Assist with planning and executing end-of-year fundraising appeals such as Giving Tuesday (November) and the Annual Appeal (November/December) Provide marketing and light social media support Qualifications: Bachelor's or Master's Level applicants only (degree-holding or currently enrolled) Proficient in Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, Publisher, PowerPoint) Excellent communication, organizational, and time-management skills Detail-oriented (have an eagle eye for typos!) Interest in working in the nonprofit sector or aging services a plus Additional Information 10-15 hours a week, 2-3 days a week (with flexibility) 3-4 months starting in November Travel stipend available (Metrocard) Our office is located on 109th Street in East Harlem To apply, please email your resume and cover letter to Kerry at mcdonaldk@carterburdennetwork.org
10029.title: Fall 2017/Early Winter 2018 Development and Events Internship

10029.description: We need a Volunteer Photographer to do photography work at our non profit organization. We need good quality photography of our programs, to help tell our clients' stories. Perfect for a photography student who wants to explore their photography skills, and great for someone who wants to offer their expert photography skills to a non profit organization that relies on telling the important stories of the most vulnerable New Yorkers. Flexibly schedule; 2 - 4 hours a week. Please email tgough@lsafhs.org with your resume.
10029.title: URGENT! Volunteer Photographer Needed!

10029.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10029.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 38 Roberto Clemente, NYC)

10026.description: Come enliven the intellect and spirit of the youngest of curious learners who are ages 3, 4, or 5! In our program, you will work with a Teacher to support the teacher in her classroom instruction. You will have the opportunity to practice your craft of becoming an early childhood instructor. Lessons that will be facilitated will concentrate in the areas of Science, Engineering, Robotics, and Art. Literacy and Math circle times will also be incorporated. Though your coursework may not concentrate in the area, as many early childhood programs do not, that's ok. Your study or experience in early childhood education is welcomed. If you are student of Education, you are welcome to develop lesson plans that center around a specific topic in your coursework, as well as video that lesson and obtain feedback from the Teacher of record. If you are an early childhood teacher, and you are in transition or are retired, you are welcome to contribute your mastery in our space. Thank you in advance!
10026.title: Calling Early Childhood Student Teachers! We're Looking For STEM PreK Instructors

10027.description: The Boys and Girls Club of Harlem is committed to providing access and opportunities for youth to reach their full potential. General Support Volunteers help achieve that goal. 10027.description: The High Expectations Department at HEAF is looking for a Youth Leadership Council YLC volunteer instructor to assist students with event planning, completing projects, and participating in organizational efforts to increase community service. The instructor(s) will bring students together to strengthen their leadership skills, relationship-building, and presentation skills. Students will partner up with community organizations to put on either fundraising events and/or service projects. YLC is a student led group, and students will also establish a HEAF centered project. Goals of the Youth Leadership Council: To empower students to participate in their own communities through stewardship. To educate students on keys issues in the community. To give students an opportunity to interact with each other and the community in a positive, constructive way. To provide opportunities to build leadership skills, self-esteem, social skills, and interpersonal relationships. Responsibilities of YLC Instructor: Design and facilitate 90 minute lessons on leadership and service learning Assist students with organizing and implementing community service events Guide students’ intellectual curiosity as they explore issues and challenges facing their community Support students growth into leaders and global citizens Qualifications /Requirements Current college students, college graduates, or graduate students Volunteer should have an interest in community service and youth leadership Volunteer must have experience with group facilitation and event planning Has a personal interest in education and youth development Patient and personable with youth Must be highly motivated

10027.description: Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. HEAF is seeking dedicated and passionate individuals to serve as academic coaches to provide tutoring and support to our College Quest (High School) students, grades 9-11. Our students need your help in the following subject areas Middle School: English Language Arts (ELA), Math (ratios, percentages, decimals, single variable equations, solving for X, plotting points on a graph) and Social Studies Time Commitment: 2:30 - 4pm, Saturdays High School: English, History (Global, U.S), Math (Trigonometry, Geometry, Algebra), Physics, Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, Spanish, French Time Commitment: 2:30-4pm, Saturdays About HEAF: The Harlem Educational Activities Fund, Inc. (HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Academic Coach Position Summary: HEAF seeks talented, passionate individuals to work with our high school students to ensure their academic success. HEAF’s College Quest program operates on weekdays from 4:30-6:30pm. Academic Coaches are asked to make at least a one hour/week commitmentfor a minimum of one semester. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles General Requirements: Desire to work with and motivate high school students to achieve academic success Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring high school students Strong work ethic and professional values Strong interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Ability and willingness to commit to academic year Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: Academic Tutor (Brooklyn)

10027.description: Sports Journalism Writer for Asphalt Green’s Community Sports Leagues Newsletter About Asphalt Green Asphalt Green is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to assisting individuals of all ages and backgrounds achieve health through a lifetime of sports and fitness. Our three main community programs reach over 33,000 New Yorkers and include: Waterproofing, which teaches elementary school children how to swim; Recess Enhancement Program, which sends a \"play coach\" to schools to get kids active during recess; and Community Sports League (CSL), which provides Harlem middle school students the chance to play interscholastic organized sports. Job Description As an integral member to the Community Sports League staff, you will be responsible for producing fun, highly detailed and engaging game write ups. You will write out the play by play, interview players, take action shots and choose your game MVP. Your submission will be included in the weekly newsletter and given out to all league participants. Location: Asphalt Green--555 East 90th Street Hours: Soccer, Saturdays 7:00pm - 9:00pm, Basketball Saturdays 10:00am-12:00pm Duration: January 2018 - June 2018 Duties: -Take notes on games every Saturday -Write a recap of each game in the style of a sports reporter. Who were the stars? Was it a close game? Was there a comeback? -Interview players, parents, coaches to add to your piece -Type up your notes and send to our newsletter coordinator by Tuesday morning -Provide general assistance to AG’s CSL staff in maintaining order and a safe, positive environment Qualifications -Excellent writing skills -Must be able to meet deadlines and respond to emails quickly -Must be creative, outgoing and able to speak with kids in a relatable way in order to get fun and full stories -Background in Sports, Communications, or other related discipline is a plus
10027.title: Sports Journalism Writer for Asphalt Green Community Sports Leagues Newsletter

(HEAF) is a comprehensive not-for-profit supplemental education and youth development organization that supports and assists dedicated students to develop the intellectual curiosity, academic ability, social values and personal resiliency they need to ensure success in school, career and life. HEAF identifies scholars in middle school and supports them until they are successfully admitted to four-year colleges through a variety of after-school, Saturday and summer programs. Academic Coach Position Summary: HEAF seeks talented, passionate individuals to work with our middle school students to ensure their academic success. HEAF’s High Expectations tutoring program operates on Saturdays from 2:30-3:30pm after our Saturday Academy program. Academic Coaches are asked to make a minimum of a one hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Please note that additional hours and responsibilities may be available depending on the interests of the academic coach. Academic Coaches provide assistance in core subjects such as Math, English, Science, and Social Studies. Coaches are matched with students based on the coach’s skills in specific subject areas and the student’s needs. Academic Coach Responsibilities: Assess and assist students in at least one of the core subjects Assist students with homework, projects, and test preparation Evaluate and record student progress Attend and participate in scheduled tutor orientation & training meetings Communicate academic progress to program staff Complete and submit required documentation Create a rich learning environment that aids in instructing students with various learning styles Teaching Assistant Position Summary HEAF seeks individuals who have a strong desire to work with middle school students to achieve academic success. As a classroom assistant, you will work alongside one of our teachers to provide supplemental support to our students. Teaching Assistants are asked to make a two hour/week commitment for a minimum of one semester. Teaching Assistants will work alongside our teachers for our Saturday Academic Elective classes. Teacher’s Assistant Responsibilities: Assist with lunch supervision Create and maintain a positive classroom culture while using effective classroom management strategies Encourage positive student behavior that promotes character development Maintain meaningful positive rapport with parents and students General Requirements for both positions: Some College or B.A. (Masters students in Education encouraged to apply) Advanced skills in Mathematics, English Language Arts, Science, Social Studies, and/or SAT Test Prep Experience tutoring middle school students Strong work ethic and interpersonal skills Willingness to promote HEAF educational and youth development philosophy. Ability to work collaboratively with the HEAF staff Bilingual (Spanish/English) candidates are highly encouraged to apply. *This position is unpaid
10027.title: Middle School Academic Coach and Teaching Assistant - Harlem

10024.description: Register at www.dorotusa.org Brighten the day of a senior! Deliver a package and visit with an older person. We offer three locations for DOROT orientation and assignments: West Side: DOROT, 171 West 85th Street, Off Amsterdam Avenue East Side: Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street, between 2nd and 3rd Avenues Westchester: Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue, East Rye, NY Manhattan: DOROT deeply appreciates the generosity of Marilyn and Stanley Katz who help sustain our Passover Package Delivery Program. We are also grateful to the estate of Sanford H. Goldstein for its support of DOROT's Holiday Package Delivery programs and to the Scheidt Charitable Foundation for the Passover Package Delivery. Thank you to Sutton Place Synagogue for hosting DOROT's East Side Package Delivery. Westchester: We are grateful to the Silverweed Foundation for its support of our Westchester Package Delivery Program. Thank you to Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester for hosting the Passover Package Delivery.
10024.title: Deliver a Passover/Spring Package and Visit with an isolated senior

10024.description: Intergenerational Chess at DOROT Youth volunteers needed to play chess with older adults and brighten their day. Share a friendship across the chess board and gain community service hours. \"One of the best things about playing chess with Mr. B is how excited we are to see each other.\" -Zach, age 13 Registration is still open on a rolling basis! Fall/Winter: Jan. 29 - May. 14 from 4:00-5:30pm Students and DOROT Seniors will get to know each other and play chess together. Refreshments will be served. Free. Requirements: for 6th - 12th grade students must commit to all sessions understand the game of chess understand the different chess pieces and how to move them Intergenerational Chess at DOROT is sponsored by the Targoff family and friends
10024.title: Intergenerational Chess - Youth Needed to Play Chess with Seniors

10024.description: Digital Grandparents (DGI), We are seeking volunteers to assist older adults with improving their technology skills during our community service program. Volunteers are needed to engage in one -on-one tutoring with older adults on Saturdays from noon to 2 PM. The organization has had 501(c)(3) status since 2010. Send an email to info@dg-inc.org with the subject line \"I want to volunteer\" if you are interested in applying to become a DGI tutor or to learn more about our program.
10024.title: Volunteers - Assist Older Adults  with the Digital World

10024.description: Volunteers at Star tutor students from low-income families who need help with reading, writing, math or other subjects. The students range in age from 2nd to 12th grade, and attend public and parochial schools across the city. About 65% of students come from families where Spanish is the primary language spoken at home. Tutors complete a written application form and interview, and are matched with an appropriate student. Once the tutor is matched, he/she receives an orientation, and then works one-to-one with the same student each week for two hours. The Center is open for tutoring on Mondays and Wednesdays from 3 to 7 pm, and on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays from 3:30 to 6 pm. You do not need to speak Spanish for this position. ***WE CURRENTLY HAVE A NUMBER OF HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WHO STILL DO NOT HAVE TUTORS! These students need primary help in Math and Science classes. The ability to help with other subjects, such as writing, would be helpful. You can apply now by visiting https://www.goddard.org/grcc/volunteer/starlearning/ and completing the Tutor Application: School Year.
10024.title: Math and Science Tutors Needed for HS Students!

10025.description: Whether you're great, good or fair at Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM), you can help make an impact on inner-city youth. Here's how: The Parris Foundation S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program has returned for the Spring 2018 session. The program began after a successful summer pilot in 2012, and our subsequent programs have grown to continue to serve middle school students and high school students . With the growing impact on the community, we need your support to continue to bring STEM to our middle school and high school youth throughout New York City. As we expand to more locations to serve more youth, there is a growing need for volunteers! How we do it: The Parris Foundation curriculum combines innovative and interactive software and teaching techniques with hand-ons interdisciplinary experiments and activities to keep our students engaged with their passion for science and math! About The Parris Foundation: The Parris Foundation is dedicated to promoting educational opportunities and fostering awareness in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) through scholarships and community outreach programs. The Parris Foundation's S.T.E.M.ulating Minds: Weekend Enrichment Programs provide extended learning opportunities to supplement and enhance in-school learning.
10025.title: Spring 2018 - S.T.E.M.ulating Minds Weekend Enrichment Program

10025.description: Top Honors is a non-profit educational organization that provides free math tutoring to NYC 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th-graders. Tutoring takes place on Saturdays and Wednesday evenings at a school on the Upper West Side. New volunteer orientation and training sessions take place on a rolling basis. To receive an invitation, please submit an application here. Frequently asked questions about the TH volunteer experience can be found on our website. All tutoring sessions take place on the Upper West Side in Manhattan on the following days and times: Session 1: Saturdays from 10 a.m. to 12 p.m. Session 2: Saturdays from 1 p.m. to 3 p.m. Session 3: Wednesdays from 6:30 p.m. to 8 p.m. Volunteers may be professionals, advanced high school, college, or graduate students (community service credit is available). Applicants should be available on Saturdays for two hours starting at 10 a.m. or 1:00 p.m. or on Wednesdays from 6:30 - 8 pm, like math, and enjoy working with students in the middle school age group (10-14 years). No prior experience is necessary. A note on volunteer commitment: Tutors attend 2-3 Saturdays from October and May, which includes holidays and school breaks. Attending 22 out of 27 scheduled sessions will meet this requirement. To apply, submit an online application at www.tophonors.org/volunteer. Upon receipt, Top Honors will contact the candidate directly.
10025.title: Do you love MATH? Volunteer MATH Tutors needed!

10020.description: March 6th, 2018|Tuesday|6:00pm-7:30pm Join us in knitting/crocheting squares to be made into blankets for the children and adolescents living in The Jewish Board residences. Enjoy soothing teas as we knit together. Beginners welcomed! We will have helpful and patient experienced knitters to help. Needles and yarn will be provided.
10020.title: Tea and Knit Night!

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 124-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated sevices on Manhattan's East Side. Our CARE program is an arts-based day program for older adults with dementia. The program provides a caring and engaging environment that allows participants to be involved in group and indvidulaized activities, while providing a respite for family caregivers. As a volunteer Program Assistant you will assist staff in leading therapeutic activities such as visual and performing arts projects, live music performances and health and welllness programs for our participants.
10021.title: Program Assistant - CARE Program for Older Adults with Dementia

10021.description: We are seeking a Japanese speaker to meet with a senior that speaks Japanese as part of Lenox Hill Neighborhood House's Friendly Visiting Program. Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, in partnership with the NYC Department for the Aging, connects volunteers with homebound older New Yorkers to have in home visits on a regular basis. For volunteers, friendly visiting offers the opportunity to cultivate a lasting friendship, to learn from a senior’s life experiences, and to benefit from the personal satisfaction derived from community service. Friendly visiting leads to the creation of meaningful relationships between older adults and volunteers, promoting intergenerational understanding. For the senior, friendly visiting provides a sense of connection to the outside world, something to look forward to, and a sense of contributing to society through sharing their wisdom, knowledge, talents and stories with you. Tasks: Have weekly social, in-home visits with an older adult you are matched with Provide monthly reports/updates to the Friendly Visiting program coordinator Requirements: Commit to being a Friendly Visitor for a minimum of six months Be comfortable establishing a relationship with an older adult Honest, mature, motivated, patient Ability to maintain confidentiality Willing and able to contact the program coordinator should problems arise Participate in an in-person interview Undergo and pass a background check and provide references Email monthly report of hours to coordinator
10021.title: Japanese Speaking Friendly Visitor Needed

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 124 year old settlement house that provides an extensive array of integrated and effective services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year, ages 3 to 103, on Manhattan's East Side. We are seeking volunteers to be part of our exciting, fast-paced live auction held during our annual Spring Gala at Cipriani 42 on East 42nd Street. Volunteers will work as a team throughout the venue to help our professional auctioneer identify when guests attending the event have placed bids on items. All proceeds from auction sakes will directly benefit programs at Lenox Hill Neighborhood House. Volunteers are needed on Wednesday, April 11th, 8:45pm-10:00pm.
10021.title: Volunteer for Spring Gala

10021.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premiere human services providers, is a 123-year old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. We are seeking volunteers who can translate short informational documents from English to Spanish in order for us to better serve the many Spanish speakers who seek help from our Legal Department for issues related to affordable housing, healthcare, workers' rights and eligibility for social service benefits.
10021.title: English/Spanish Translation

10036.description: Help rescue some lunch leftovers from an office in Midtown West! We will deliver the food to Travelers Hotel, located at 274 W 40th street. Mediumweight: the average amount of food rescued from this event is 30-45 pounds.
10036.title: End Food Waste and Feed the Hungry Fridays 3PM!

10036.description: You will have a great time meeting as many people as possible at various events and inviting them to upcoming productions that make a difference and begin crucial conversations.
10036.title: Fun social butterfly volunteering!

10036.description: Love to dance and love working with children! Seeking Intermediate level ballet teacher for an amazing group of talented 8-14yr olds. Basic knowledge of ballet technique is required. Come help teach the awesome kids of the Hell's Kitchen Community!
10036.title: Children's Ballet Teacher!

10036.description: Come join us as we educate children about healthy eating, food, and taste. Training Dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM What is Spoons Across America? Spoons Across America (SAA) is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to educating children, teachers, and families about the benefits of healthy eating though food and nutrition-based educational programs for children. What is Agriculture Literacy Week? Spoons Across America is the primary New York City implementer of Cornell Cooperative Extension’s New York Agriculture Literacy Week. In this free program for New York City schools, 1st and 2nd graders learn about New York state agriculture - what kinds of food are grown and produced in the state, and the people who are involved in growing and producing them. Spoons Across America trains volunteers to read a selected storybook and lead a related curriculum activity. Between March 12 and April 25, 2018, volunteers will read Before We Eat: From Farm to Table by Pat Brisson. Students will be taken on the journey from farm to table to understand different aspects of agriculture and the many possible careers involved. This is a captivating glimpse of what it takes to bring the food we eat to us in order to nourish our bodies and spirits. What do Volunteers do? After participating in a hands-on training, volunteers participate in and lead all aspects of Agriculture Literacy Week implementation. Volunteer responsibilities include reading the Agriculture Literacy Week book aloud to the class, leading an activity related to the book, and set up and clean up. We are looking for individuals enthusiastic about healthy eating and children’s programming to join us! Volunteer Training: All volunteers receive training at the Spoons Across America offices (630 Ninth Avenue @ 44th Street in Manhattan), and are required to attend one of the following training dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM **** Do you work for a business or company that wants to make a volunteer commitment? We can schedule a special training session for groups of 10 or more people, onsite or at our offices. Contact Ali for more information. When do your programs take place? Agriculture Literacy Week programs occur DURING SCHOOL HOURS. Please be advised that there are no after-work hours available for Agriculture Literacy Week. I'm ready to go! How do I sign up? If you are interested in volunteering with Spoons Across America this year, please contact Ali McDowell, Director of Programs and Partnerships, at ali@spoonsacrossamerica.org. In your email, please indicate which training session you will attend: Monday, February 26th at 5:30 PM or Wednesday, February 28th at 12:00 PM. * Please note: Volunteers must complete a background check prior to the program date.
10036.title: New York Agriculture Literacy Week - join us in the classroom!
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America

10036.description: The Imperial Court of New York (ICNY), the state's most regal organization serving the LGBT community and people living with HIV/AIDS since 1986, will host the 32 nd annual Night of a Thousand Gowns on 7 April 2018. The ball will be held at the Marriott Marquis in Times Square on Saturday, April 7 April, and is presented by the ICNY and our reigning Monarchs H.M.I.S.M Emperor XXVI Harrington and H.I.M. Empress XXIX and Regent Empress XXXI Madison Mansfield. The ICNY is happy to announce that the event will benefit God’s Love We Deliver. Our sponsors for the 32 nd ball include: Stoli, JetBlue Airways, Barefoot Wines, Miller Coors and Manhattan Mini Storage. About the Imperial Court of New York: The Imperial Court of New York, a 501(c)3 corporation, is New York's most regal fundraising organization serving the LGBT community for the past 32 years. Part of a proud tradition, the Court has raised millions of dollars for charitable organizations serving the LGBT community and our partners. For more information, please visit: http://icny.org. ###
10036.title: 32nd Night of a Thousand Gowns
10036.org: Imperial Court of New York, Inc.

10017.description: The Event Chair serves as the lead volunteer for implementation of the St. Jude Walk/Run to End Childhood Cancer in their community. The Event Chair engages community members to serve in subcommittee roles while developing and implementing a successful annual community event to raise funds and awareness of St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital. A successful Event Chair possesses strong organization, leadership and communication skills. This individual is able to commit approximately 10-15 hours a month to St. Jude Walk/Run efforts.
10017.title: St. Jude Walk/Run to End Childhood Cancer - Event Chair (Jersey Shore, NJ)

10017.description: We are organizing a Conference and Community event at Columbia University on February 27th. We need people help us actively find participants to come to the event! The topic of the event is \"Own Your Health. Making Mindful Choices at Any Age\". The concept is that there is a lot that people can do to take care of their health, just by their daily choices and behaviors. Also, the idea that we should always be mindful of our health, from when we are very young to our elderly years. It also speaks to the idea of patient-centered approaches and natural and preventive methods to take care of our health. Ultimately, it aims to help people realize that we can do a lot with our own body and mind to prevent and/or make better use of medication, doctor's appointments and operations. The event is co-sponsored by the World Health Organization and the NGO Committee on Mental Health. We really need people to help us register participants!!!! The volunteer would be responsible for applying different strategies including mostly Social Media and Email Marketing and Outreach. All the proceeds of the conference will help IBREA start off its Holistic Training Center in Harlem.
10017.title: Promotion and Social Media, Getting participants for conference

10030.description: Future Giants is a non profit that has operated in NYC for over 11 years. We specialize in preparing High School students for the social and academic challenges they will encounter after graduation. We have a 100 college acceptance rate and a 99 % on time High School Graduation rate. Last year we created and published a High school book that is being used in several High Schools. We are seeking Volunteers that have a direct or indirect contact with the Mayors of Baltimore and or D.C. It is our hope to recreate our success in those cities as well as open our first multi organization youth center (A.C.E) Future Giants is planning to Launch our Academic + Community = Excellence If you have any contacts with the Mayors of either Baltimore ,MD or D.C ( or the Governor) we would like your assistance in helping thousands of young people achieve their dreams.
10030.title: Reference to Mayor of D.C. and or Baltimore

10030.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10030.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 123, Manhattan)

10111.description: The National MS Society is looking for volunteers to cheer on participants at Climb to the Top NYC! Climb to the Top NYC 2018 will be held on Sunday, March 4th at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan. We welcome groups and individuals of all ages & abilities to join us as volunteers! This is a unique event that the New York City - Southern New York market of the National MS Society hosts to raise awareness and funds for the 12,000 people living with MS that we serve in the five boroughs and Westchester, Putnam, Rockland, Orange and Sullivan counties. More than 300 volunteers are needed to make this event a success. If you are interested in volunteering, please review the position below and register online here: www.climbMSnyc.org Volunteer Check-In Team Date: Sunday, March 4 Location: Rockefeller Center Time: 4:30am-10:00am Description: Volunteers will check-in volunteers and direct them to assigned locations. Climb to the Top NYC 2018 will be held on Sunday, March 4th at Rockefeller Center in Manhattan. We welcome groups and individuals of all ages & abilities to join us as volunteers! 10075.description: Exciting high school competition taking place at the Astor House in Manhattan. Event volunteers needed for Thursday, March 22, 2018. 8:00 a.m. - 3:00 p.m. (We can arrange an early departure at 1:00 pm, if needed) Possible Responsibilities include: Assisting at registration, escorting teams presenting from waiting room to presentation rooms, managing waiting and post presentation rooms, setup and cleanup. Breakfast and lunch is provided. Photo ID required. Euro Challenge The Euro Challenge, a program of the Delegation of the European Union to the United States, provides a unique opportunity for 9 th and 10 th grade students across the United States to learn about the Euro Area and the countries that use its single currency, the euro. Organized as a competition, the program invites students to step into the shoes of diplomats and economic policymakers by examining real-world economic challenges facing countries in the Euro Area. Working in teams of 3-5, students make presentations to a panel of judges about the current state of the Euro Area economy. They also select a Euro Area country, examine an economic challenge facing that country, and recommend policy prescriptions. More info on the competition can be found at: http://www.euro-challenge.org
10075.title: Euro Challenge: NY Preliminary Round

10019.description: Saturday, March 17 | 8am - 4pm (in 3 hours shifts) Volunteer for a fun St. Patrick’s Day tradition! - Irish Arts Center’s Annual Book Day On St. Patrick’s Day, March 17th, each year, we rely on great volunteers to help us hand out free books by Irish and Irish-American authors across the boroughs of New York City. Volunteer shifts can be suited to your availability and we try our best to match people to the borough of their choice. For more information and to sign up please fill out our availability survey here: https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/S8TKMQV If you aren't available on Book Day itself, Saturday, March 17th, don't fret! A large part of the event prep depends on your help in making sure each book has an Irish Arts Center sticker and bookmark. Volunteering for these \"stuffing\" days is a fun way to get involved with the center in a relaxed environment. We’ll have flexible hours available during the weeks leading up to Book Day, so if you’re still interested in helping out, please let me know and I’ll keep you up to date on details. If you have any questions, please email: iacbookday@gmail.com or call (212) 757-3318 extension 203. \"This is a lovely way to remind everybody that the Irish are known for their literature.\" - The Wall Street Journal In a citywide celebration of Irish literature we'll be handing out 10,000 free books and want you to be part of the fun!
10019.title: St. Patrick's Day Book Giveaway with Irish Arts Center!

10019.description: Together One New York (TONY) is starting a new program to teach Spanish. The volunteering opportunity will generally be weekday evenings between 6 and 9 PM. Prior teaching experience a plus, but certainly not required. TONY is a non-profit organization whose volunteers are passionate about providing vital resources to all members of the NYC community, with a special emphasis on immigrants and language learning. In addition to language classes, we offer a variety of programs such as Citizenship Prep, TASC (high school equivalency), and beginner ESOL conversation. We look forward to expanding our outreach and positively impacting a greater portion of our city's immigrant community.

10019.description: It is difficult and sometimes impossible for seniors to travel by themselves to necessary appointments such as doctors and dentist appointments, and on necessary errands such as food shopping. The Senior Escort program makes these crucial trips possible. Encore’s Senior Escort Program is a volunteer program designed to give much needed assistance and support to aging members of our community. Otherwise, due to physical frailty and disability, vision or hearing impairment, and cognitive problems, our senior neighbors are forced to cancel their trips - which leads to rapid decline in health and quality of life. Things to know: As a volunteer, you will meet the senior at their front door, accompany them to their appointment or errand, and then accompany them back to their home. Trips typically take 1-3 hours, depending on the circumstance. You will travel via public transportation (each individual is responsible for their own metro card) or via cab (the senior participant is responsible for cab fees) The clients we serve live in Manhattan south of 110th Duties include: Helping the older person dress in outerwear such as coat, sweater or hat for the trip Helping the older person lock and unlock his/her residence Helping the older person with physical strains such as assistance on stairs and carrying/pushing the grocery cart Requirements: Commitment of at least 6 months Weekly commitments, preferred Successful criminal background check & reference check Flexible hours Monday-Friday and/or available at least one day a week Attend program orientation & training Must be at least 18 years old Sensitive and empathic with the senior population *Important* Schedule: The program is not a fixed schedule. Requests come in every week, at different times and days Monday-Friday. Volunteers must have flexibility during the work week, i.e. a part-time job, or flexible work hours. It is required that you have at least one entire day free from Monday-Friday, we will place the volunteer on an on-call basis depending on the requests that come in that week. Your role as a volunteer in this program is incredibly valuable and rewarding. Senior program participants are so grateful for your time and help. It is a simple but vital service.
10019.title: Volunteers Needed… Please Accompany A Senior To Medical Appointment/Grocery Shopping. THANK YOU!

10019.description: Estamos buscando un voluntario para acompañar a un encantador señor de 90+ años. Él vive en la parte sureste de la ciudad de New York. A él le encanta jugar domin ó , mirar noticias y novelas. Él te necesita solo una hora a la semana. GRACIAS. We match isolated and lonely seniors with volunteers in the community who make weekly visits in the senior’s home. The Friendly Visiting program is an opportunity to form rewarding relationships and ongoing companionship for both seniors and volunteers. Seniors and their visitor can converse and enjoy the company, take part in activities like going to cafes and museums, share stories, learn new skills, and a variety of other things based on the desires of the companions. You will be matched with a senior who has a similar personality and interests and you can decide together how to spend your time. Visits can easily fit into your schedule because matches are made based on your availability. We ask for a minimum commitment of 6 months or 1 year. Your time as a friendly visitor is invaluable, and you gain a new friend!
10019.title: ¿Voluntario? Por Favor Acompaña A Un Simpático Señor De 90+ Años Solo Una Hora Por Semana.

10018.description: America Needs You fights for economic mobility for ambitious, first generation college students. We do this by providing transformative mentorship and intensive career development. Our flagship Fellows Program is a two-year, intensive mentoring and professional training program where first-generation students (\"Fellows\") are paired with young professional volunteers. Our New York program workshops take place in Manhattan and Brooklyn. Career Coaches work with college students during Saturday sessions to build their professional skills and help them realize their career potential. ANY curriculum covers all kinds of professional development topics from resume preparation and interview etiquette to giving and receiving feedback and managing up. At workshops, Career Coaches typically participate in group or one-on-one work with Fellows; for example, writing and reviewing a cover letter or building a pros/cons list for deciding between two internships. Please complete the survey below to be contacted about volunteering at an upcoming workshop: https://newyorkneedsyou.wufoo.com/forms/rn5685a0sqkdux/
10018.title: Volunteer to mentor ambitious first-generation college students!

10038.description: Help make the 2018 Project G.L.A.M Prom Boutique a reality! Volunteer to be Fairy Godmother on April 20th, 21st, or 22nd in Manhattan, NY! 10038.description: About Reach the World is a New York City-based nonprofit organization that makes the benefits of travel accessible to classrooms, inspiring students to become curious, confident and compassionate global citizens. Every year since 2001, Reach the World has held an annual benefit to fundraise for the organization. The guest count is typically between 150 and 200 guests from diverse New York City and Connecticut-based industries. The event format includes cocktails, a silent auction, a sit-down dinner, and an award presentation at the end of the evening. This year's Cronkite Award will be given to a prominent honoree- stay tuned for the big reveal! The success of Reach the World's events are entirely dependent on the volunteer Benefit Committee members whose work and creativity make each event possible. Volunteering for RTW is a substantive way to gain event experience, network with other NYC professionals, and give back to a good cause. Reach the World welcomes all serious applicants to the 2018 Benefit Committee. The 2018 Benefit will take place on April 4 th, 2018 at the Boathouse in Central Park. To apply and for more information, please fill out this online application: https://www.tfaforms.com/4651651
10038.title: Join Reach the World's 2018 Annual Benefit Committee

10038.description: Do you have a passion for global education and international exchange? Do you believe in grassroots programs that leverage volunteer energies for a social good? Are you excited by events and production? Reach the World is seeking a mature volunteer looking to advance his/her networking, fundraising and event management skills for a 'team lead’ position of Reach the World’s 2018 Benefit Committee. This volunteer position (4-10h/week) reports to RTW's Development Manager. This position has a flexible start date between December 1, 2017 and January 2, 2018 and runs until the gala on April 6th 2018. The position is unpaid. The volunteer who secures the most donations receives two tickets to the event and is entered into the raffle! Responsibilities: Event Planning: Participate in bi-weekly evening meetings; lead the strategy for securing fashion prize donations for the silent auction; manage other volunteers Fashion Industry Outreach and Donor Management: Reach out to donors in person, through email and over the phone to secure a minimum of 25 fashion prizes for the silent auction (women’s, men’s, kids, home, office); leverage network to increase donations; manage relationships with donors in the fashion industry Gala Volunteering: Volunteer at the event (unless you plan to purchase a ticket and attend) Qualifications: Organized self-starter Fearless communicator Works well under pressure Team player Experience planning events and/or volunteering with a nonprofit is a bonus About Reach the World and the 2018 Annual Benefit Dinner Reach the World makes the benefits of travel accessible to classrooms, inspiring students to become curious, confident global citizens. Enabled by our virtual exchange platform, classrooms and volunteer travelers explore the world together. Every year since 2001, Reach the World has held an annual benefit to fundraise for the organization. The event includes cocktails, a silent auction, a sit-down dinner, and an award presentation at the end of the evening. This year's Cronkite Award will be given to a prominent honoree - stay tuned! The success of Reach the World's event is entirely dependent on the volunteer Benefit Committee members whose work and creativity make the event possible. Volunteering for RTW is a substantive way to gain event experience, network with other NYC professionals, and give back to a good cause. How to Apply Please submit a cover letter and resume by email to brianna@reachtheworld.org. No phone, email, mail, or fax inquiries will receive a response. Thank you for your interest in joining Reach the World on its exciting journey!
10038.title: Fashion Prize Manager

Responsibilities: Event Planning: Participate in bi-weekly evening meetings; lead the strategy for securing entertainment prize donations for the silent auction; manage other volunteers Outreach and Donor Management: Reach out to donors in person, through email and over the phone to secure a minimum of 25 entertainment prizes for the silent auction (tickets to sports, movies, theater; fitness classes; unique experiences); leverage network to increase donations; manage relationships with donors Gala Volunteering: Volunteer at the event (unless you plan to purchase a ticket and attend) Qualifications: Organized self-starter Fearless communicator Works well under pressure Team player Experience planning events and/or volunteering with a nonprofit is a bonus About Reach the World and the 2018 Annual Benefit Dinner Reach the World makes the benefits of travel accessible to classrooms, inspiring students to become curious, confident global citizens. Enabled by our virtual exchange platform, classrooms and volunteer travelers explore the world together. Every year since 2001, Reach the World has held an annual benefit to fundraise for the organization. The event includes cocktails, a silent auction, a sit-down dinner, and an award presentation at the end of the evening. This year's Cronkite Award will be given to a prominent honoree - stay tuned! The success of Reach the World's event is entirely dependent on the volunteer Benefit Committee members whose work and creativity make the event possible. Volunteering for RTW is a substantive way to gain event experience, network with other NYC professionals, and give back to a good cause. How to Apply Please submit a cover letter and resume by email to brianna@reachtheworld.org. No phone, email, mail, or fax inquiries will receive a response. Thank you for your interest in joining Reach the World on its exciting journey!
10038.title: Entertainment Prize Manager

10038.description: American Youth Table Tennis seeks interested college students in the New York City Metro Area to teach high school students the sport of table tennis, leadership, fair play, respect and teamwork. Table Tennis expertise required. As a volunteer coach you will receive a small per visit stipend per visit to cover transportation costs and effort. We will assign you to a New York City High School Table Tennis Program as an Assistant Table Tennis Coach. Duties will include, teaching basic and intermediate table tennis - footwork, serve, serve return, backhand, forehand, tactics, loop, loop drive as well as serving multi-ball and providing a positive and exciting framework for play, and dialog. American Youth Table Tennis and New York City Department of Education have teamed up to make this opportunity available to you. Table Tennis is an official varsity sport in New York City. We will be accepting applications in November and through to the end of January. We are in need of expert collegiate table tennis players to assist in selected High School Programs for the 2017-18 season which begins in December and Continues through March 2018 As an Assistant Coach, you will be giving back to the New York City community by imparting your table tennis knowledge on receptive and interested high school students. This program will look good on your resume and will help the next generation of collegiate table tennis players.
10038.title: Youth Table Tennis Coach - Collegiate Internship Program

10038.description: Mentor a 13-18 year old student to provide guidance and broaden his or her horizons. Help a student grow to be confident, caring young adult by becoming a role model and someone he or she can rely on. Mentors and mentees are matched after carefully considering the goals of the mentee and what the mentor can do to support that goal. We are currently looking for more male mentors. The mentoring program is for males and females, but as of now, we do not have enough male mentors.
10038.title: Middle School/High School Mentor (male)

10038.description: Teach 4th and 5th graders the fundamentals of basketball and what teamwork really is. Coach the students and help them win games against other schools by guiding them through the seasons. Be the one to show the young students the love for the game.
10038.title: Volunteer Basketball Coaches Needed

10038.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10038.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 126 Jacob August Riis, Manhattan)

10038.description: We are looking for volunteers with dance experience to help run a weekly movement-based creative workshop for students with intellectual disabilities in Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, Wednesdays from 11-12. This opportunity takes place over 12 weeks, for a small group of middle and high school students. The workshop will culminate with an informal showing. We are also looking for volunteer yoga instructors in all boroughs.
10038.title: Looking for Dance Teachers and Yoga Instructors

The Boys and Girls Club of Harlem is committed to providing access and opportunities for youth to reach their full potential. General Support Volunteers help achieve that goal. The Boys and Girls Club serves members from 5-18 and increasing the adult to member count allows a more meaningful experience for members. Support volunteers allow us to run programs more effectively because there are more individuals to assist in facilitation. Key Responsibilities: Club Support volunteers will assist club staff as well as members to ensure a fun and safe environment for all. This role is to ensure our members are getting the most out of their club experience. Provide programmatic and operational support to the organization. This could be academic support, walking students to different programs and assisting staff with program facilitation.
10035.title: General Support Volunteer

We have opportunities for everyone, including groups: distribute T-Shirts, pass out refreshments for walkers/runners, accept donations and so much more. Please feel free to call the Colon Cancer Challenge Foundation at 914.305.6674 or email at info@coloncancerchallenge.org with any questions or concerns.
10035.title: The 15th Annual Colon Cancer Challenge

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org We are looking for one individual to support our volunteer coordinator in volunteer recruitment, management, and training. Be a part of one of Housing Works' biggest fundraising events of the year, Design on a Dime, while improving your administrative skills and supporting our volunteer recruitment efforts! The individual will support the volunteer coordinator by doing the following: Researching and recruiting groups and individuals that may be interested in volunteering at our annual Design on a Dime Basic data entry (Salesforce CRM) Answering emails and calls professionally and promptly Administrative task as needed Committing to about 5-10 hours a week Must be available to provide support the final week of April If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment. You must send an email to be considered; requests via VolunteerMatch will not be accepted. Must be 18 or older.
10012.title: Volunteer Recruitment Opportunity!

If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment.
10012.title: Design on a Dime Data Entry Volunteer

10011.description: The Purple & White Fight Night was founded by Danyelle Shapiro and Ashley Janover, who each lost a loved one to cancer. The event is hosted in memory of Danyelle’s father, who lost his life to lung cancer at age 41, and Ashley’s mother, who lost her battle to pancreatic cancer at age 54. Proceeds from the event will be evenly dispersed between the Lung Cancer Research Foundation and the Hirshberg Foundation for Pancreatic Cancer Research. The event is from 8:00 pm to 11:00 pm but we are looking for volunteers to arrive at 7:00 pm and stay until midnight. We are looking for volunteers to help with set-up, raffle assistance, selling raffle tickets, and clean-up.
10011.title: Fourth Annual Purple & White Fight Night

10011.description: GRANT WRITER The Grant Writer is primarily responsible for developing and writing grant proposals to foundations and other grant-making organizations, and will persuasively communicate CSP's mission and programs to potential funders. Reporting to the Executive Director, the Grant Writer will assemble and submit grant requests, establish and maintain personal contact and relationships with foundation contacts, conduct prospect research, and maintain a calendar of submissions and other deadlines. To get a response please send RESUME.
10011.title: Grant Writer

10011.description: Education Program Coordinator - Chelsea Sculpture Park. New York , New York. Basic Requirements: BA or MA in related discipline required (Art Education) Post college professional work experience required Demonstrated experience with art education or other informal art programming and curriculum design Demonstrated knowledge of Microsoft computer programs and excellent presentation skills Job Responsibilities: Coordinate and develop of new partner-institution/organization relationships and curriculum Provide leadership and direction towards the design and implementation of art educational programming and curriculum in compliance with national and state learning objectives, accreditation guidelines, and innovative art methodologies Establish and grow professional relationships with constituents, peers, associations and partner schools To Apply: Please submit your resume with cover letter and references to the contact information listed below. Set against the backdrop of the Hudson River, Chelsea Sculpture Park will offer fine art for the public to experience, up close and outdoors. The park's mission is to provide an aesthetic oasis in the Chelsea Cove section of Hudson River Park located between 22nd and 26th Streets, just steps away from the world-class Chelsea Art District. We are looking for a Education Program Coordinator to assist the founder and executive-director of Chelsea Sculpture Park develop and implement an educational program foccusing on the exhibitions of the sculpture park.
10011.title: Educational Program - Coordinator

10011.description: Chelsea Sculpture Park New York, New York Are you considering a future in arts administration, nonprofit management, fundraising, arts education or a related field? This is a great opportunity to gain experience working at a brand new nonprofit arts organization that is dedicated to building a sculpture park on the banks of the Hudson River Park. Gain invaluable insights and learn fundraising strategies as part of a dynamic Development team. Assist with prospect research, special events, direct mail, and our donor database, as well as pursue special projects. Internship credit may be arranged through your academic program. The ideal candidate will be organized and detail-oriented, and have good computer skills. Those with prospect research experience and graduate students in arts administration and arts education are especially welcome. The hours for this position are flexible within the work week. A modest stipend is available. To Apply: Please be sure to include current contact information so that we may arrange an interview. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Development Intern

10011.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our non-profit organization. By volunteering, you are directly responsible for providing funding to and advocating for New Yorkers affected by homelessness and HIV/AIDS. Thank you for your interest in volunteering at Design on a Dime 2018! Each year, DOD depends on the hard work of hundreds of volunteers. You can volunteer to help in many ways, including event setup, sales and breakdown. This is a great opportunity for individuals looking to get involved with Housing Works, as well as groups looking to volunteer! Opportunities are available throughout the last week of April, with shifts in the morning, afternoon, and evening. Please email volunteer@housingworks.org for a complete schedule. All participating volunteers will receive a brand new Design on a Dime 2018 t-shirt along with a 25% discount card to be used during our Public Sale Days or at one of our Thrift Shops (valid for 30 days). If you are interested in volunteering, or would like to sign up your group to volunteer for Design on a Dime 2018 please email volunteers@housingworks.org.
10011.title: Design On a Dime 2018, Great for Groups and Individuals!

10011.description: Do you have a passion for dance? Do you enjoy working with children? Are you looking to gain experience and new skills? then volunteering with Dance to Unite, Inc. could be the right volunteer opportunity for you! Dance to Unite, Inc. is a non-profit organization whose mission is to use dance as a vehicle to teach and to celebrate cultural diversity. WE ARE LOOKING FOR VOLUNTEER DANCE TEACHERS AND TEACHER ASSISTANTS! Qualified applicants are required to have some background in dance but most imporatntly a strong interest and desire to work with inner city children and youth. A one hour weekly comittment is required throughout the school year (October-June) and availability during after-school hours (3:00-6:00pm). We offer FREE training in a warm and supportive environment with plently of opportunities for professional and personal growth. Responsibilities of Volunteer Dance Teachers: -Become familiar and comfortable with implementing our educational component which includes leading our 5-10 minutes 'Circle Talk' . *We provide supervision, guidance and support to ensure that everyone is properly trained and fully prepared to implement our educational component. -Create and teach a year-round dance routine and choose the music that will accompany your choreography. -Facilitate one special guest artist workshop (which is offered to each Dance to Unite, Inc. Class throught the school year) by briefing students about the style of dance or other artistic medium which is explored that day and collaborate with all those involved in making the workshop a success. Responsibilities of Dance Teacher Assistants: -Work closely with a teacher and support her/his efforts in fulfilling all of her/his duties/responsibilities. -Participate in/or lead a weekly warm-up exercise routine. -Learn the choreography taught by the teacher by rehearsing a weekly dance routine with the students. -Assist the teacher with running/managing the classroom by providing positive feedback and addressing inappropriate behaviors when needed. -Periodically take photos/videos that can be used for our social media (using a camera phone). Benefits of these volunteer opportunities: -Gain knowledge/experience and develop various set of skills related to creating a year-round dance choreography, leading a short discussion and managing a classroom. -Receive references and recommendation letters as evidence to support your accomplishments when applying for internships, jobs or graduate schools. *Internship opportunities are available to both high school and college students. -Recieve free training in a warm and supportive environment that offers countless opportunities for professional and personal growth. -Volunteers who have been with us long enough to show commitment and dedication to our organization are acknowledged by being featured on our organization's website. -Cultivate new personal and professional contacts. -Receive a free invitation to our annual benefit and other events. -Join our Dance to Unite, Inc. Meetup group and meet like-minded people in the local community who share a passion for making a difference. THANK YOU FOR YOUR INTEREST IN JOINING OUR DANCE TO UNITE FAMILY! For further information, please check our website: www.dancetounite.org FOR QUESTIONS AND INQUIRIES, PLEASE CONTACT: info@dancetounite.org
10011.title: Teach dance to inner city kids!

10031.description: The Boys & Girls Club of Harlem’s (BGCHarlem) mission is to provide access and opportunity for youth to reach their full potential as responsible members of the community. We believe that success is within reach of every young person that walks through our doors. Our kids benefit from trained, caring professional staff and volunteers who help them take control of their lives, envision productive futures and reach the goals. Core to this is the development of strong character and leadership skills and we seek your support to both models and encourage them as a volunteer group mentor for our Girls mentoring program. Our Girls mentoring program provides girls ages 8-17, with the skills to develop positive self-esteem, and adopt healthy lifestyle habits. Weekly participants engage in discussions on a range of topics that include media influences on females, dating relationships, and health prevention and education. Volunteers, with the support of BGCHarlem staff, will help to facilitate these discussions over a 10-week session, guiding youth through a curriculum that builds competencies in: Understanding and implementing the Boys and Girls Club of Harlem program Having in-depth and potentially uncomfortable conversations about challenges facing teens today Discussing nutrition, cooking and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. Our Boys Mentoring program uses interactive activities to educate males 8-12 and 13-17 on the critical issues that young men face including decision making, wellness, careers and employment, relationships, and self-esteem This opportunity is on Monday evenings.
10031.title: Boys and Girls Group Mentoring

10016.description: In Commemoration of International Women's Day during the United Nations CSW62 (Commission on the Status of Women 62) Join the Panel Discussion on Challenges & Opportunities in Empowering Rural Girls for SDG5. Task description: Work together on creating photo/video content strategy for our company Be responsible for styling and taking pictures for our social media, email campaigns, website, Youtube, etc. Skills: Creativity and inspiration Ability to take good photos and videos Need to be a team player Interest, education or experience in photography, videography or marketing will be a plus Must be 18 years and resides in New York City.
10016.title: Photographer/Videographer

10016.description: GO Project Spanish Translator (Saturday Volunteer) GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Spanish in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs. Specific Translator duties will include: Saturdays Assist with parent meetings, workshops and orientations for Spanish speaking families. Provide interpretation for our families, including any cultural/linguistic references that may need to be explained. Maintain our families’ right to confidentiality. Collaborate with GO Staff, Volunteer Manager, Head Teachers and GO Families Staff to address and respond to our students’/ families’ needs. Time Commitment The position would require a commitment to our GO School Saturday program. We can accommodate a semester schedule or a full year commitment. Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 13 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications: Excellent verbal and written communication skills. Interest in strength-based collaborative work, education and social services. Ability to speak Spanish. Prior experience in simultaneous and consecutive interpretation is a plus. Personal Attributes: The ideal candidate is exceptionally intelligent, warm, engaging and energetic. He or she also: Sees the possibilities as opposed to the obstacles and is creative and tenacious in solving problems. Enjoys working with others in a collaborative, creative environment. Has a strong work ethic and high standards for his/her own work and the work of others; is flexible and has a lively sense of humor. Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.
10016.title: Saturday Spanish Translator Needed!

10016.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of (2) to (4) students on the lesson providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1 st-8 th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session. (Session 1: Oct-Dec, Session 2: Jan-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - supporting instruction and engagement Help prepare, record and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding children’s progress &/or concerns, and with the Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience. Time Commitment Session I: October- December 2017, 9 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Session II: January - April 2018, 14 Saturdays 9am - 12:45 pm Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall Session Dates 2017 Oct 14, 21, 28 Nov 4, 11, 18 Dec 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring Session Dates 2018 Jan 6, 20, 27 Feb 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations: Avenues-the World School (1st - 5th Grade): 259 10 th Avenue, between 25 th and 26 th Streets Grace Church School (1st - 5th Grade): 86 4 th Avenue, between 10 th and 11 th Streets Grace Church High School (6th - 8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6 th Street LREI (1st - 5th Grade): 272 6 th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s (1st - 3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson Street and Christopher Street Brooklyn Location: Berkeley Carroll (1 st - 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6 th & 7 th Ave Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing. Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners. Ongoing professional development and training opportunities. Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment. Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community. How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with the GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/ High school transcript (for HS students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2 . The online application form can also be found on the GO Project website: goprojectnyc.org under \"Get Involved\" and \"Volunteer Opportunities.\" If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact Emily Ong, Community Engagement Program Manager, at eong@goprojectnyc.org.
10016.title: Help a Child Love to Learn: Volunteer Tutor with GO Project!

10016.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Programming: How YOU Can Help GO Schoolis a focused, seven-month Saturday program with a staff of certified teachers and skilled volunteer tutors. Students attend on Saturdays between October and April for a half-day of focused academic skill-building. Professional teachers lead lessons, support volunteer tutors, and communicate with parents to keep them informed about their child’s progress. Volunteer tutors commit to a semester of volunteering in a classroom and mentor their students to provide consistent and individualized needed to succeed. Volunteer translators provide critical communication support between our GO families and our staff. Interpreters are responsible for translating English into Chinese (both Mandarin and Cantonese) in order for our program to communicate with our families regarding program updates and their child’s academic & social-emotional progress/needs.
